Description: Items in this section are advised for all systems but may be difficult or require extensive preparation after the initial setup of the system.

children.Summary: 1.1 Filesystem
children.Description: The file system is generally a built-in layer used to handle the data management of the storage

children.Summary: 1.1.1 Configure Filesystem Kernel Modules
children.Description: A number of uncommon filesystem types are supported under Linux. Removing support for unneeded filesystem types reduces the local attack surface of the system. If a filesystem type is not needed it should be disabled. Native Linux file systems are designed to ensure that built-in security controls function as expected. Non-native filesystems can lead to unexpected consequences to both the security and functionality of the system and should be used with caution. Many filesystems are created for niche use cases and are not maintained and supported as the operating systems are updated and patched. Users of non-native filesystems should ensure that there is attention and ongoing support for them, especially in light of frequent operating system changes. Standard network connectivity and Internet access to cloud storage may make the use of non-standard filesystem formats to directly attach heterogeneous devices much less attractive

children.Summary: 1.1.1.1 Ensure cramfs kernel module is not available
children.Description: The cramfs filesystem is a compressed read-only filesystem that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.Summary: 1.1.1.2 Ensure freevxfs kernel module is not available
children.Description: The freevxfs filesystem is a read-only filesystem that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.Summary: 1.1.1.3 Ensure hfs kernel module is not available
children.Description: The hfs filesystem is an older filesystem used primarily by Apple systems and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.Summary: 1.1.1.4 Ensure hfsplus kernel module is not available
children.Description: The hfsplus filesystem is an updated version of the hfs filesystem used by Apple systems and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.Summary: 1.1.1.5 Ensure jffs2 kernel module is not available
children.Description: The jffs2 filesystem is a journaling flash filesystem that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.Summary: 1.1.1.6 Ensure squashfs kernel module is not available
children.Description: The squashfs filesystem is a compressed read-only filesystem that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.Summary: 1.1.1.7 Ensure udf kernel module is not available
children.Description: The udf filesystem is a universal disk format that is not commonly used and can pose security risks if left enabled.

children.Summary: 1.1.1.8 Ensure usb-storage kernel module is not available
children.Description: The usb-storage kernel module allows the system to access USB storage devices. If USB storage is not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 1.1.2 Configure Filesystem Partitions
children.Description: Partitioning the filesystem can enhance security by isolating critical directories and preventing unauthorized access to sensitive data. It also helps in managing disk space more effectively.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.1 Configure /tmp
children.Description: The /tmp directory is used for temporary file storage. Configuring it as a separate partition can prevent unauthorized access and ensure that temporary files do not consume space on the root filesystem.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.1.1 Ensure /tmp is separate partition
children.Description: Having /tmp as a separate partition can help prevent unauthorized access to temporary files and ensure that the root filesystem is not filled with temporary data.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.1.2 Ensure nodev option set on /tmp partition
children.Description: The nodev option prevents the creation of device files in the /tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.1.3 Ensure nosuid option is set on /tmp partition
children.Description: The nosuid option prevents the execution of setuid and setgid programs in the /tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.1.4 Ensure noexec option is set on /tmp partition
children.Description: The noexec option prevents the execution of binaries in the /tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.2 Configure /dev/shm
children.Description: The /dev/shm directory is used for shared memory. Configuring it as a separate partition can enhance security by isolating shared memory from other filesystems.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.2.1 Verify /dev/shm is mounted as a separate partition
children.Description: Having /dev/shm as a separate partition can help prevent unauthorized access to shared memory and ensure that it does not consume space on the root filesystem.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.2.2 Ensure nodev option is set on /dev/shm partition
children.Description: The nodev option prevents the creation of device files in the /dev/shm directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.2.3 Ensure nosuid option is set on /dev/shm partition
children.Description: The nosuid option prevents the execution of setuid and setgid programs in the /dev/shm directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.2.4 Ensure noexec option set on /dev/shm partition
children.Description: The noexec option prevents the execution of binaries in the /dev/shm directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.3 Configure /home
children.Description: The /home directory is used for user home directories. Configuring it as a separate partition can enhance security by isolating user data from system files and preventing unauthorized access to sensitive user data.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.3.1 Ensure separate partition exists for /home
children.Description: Having /home as a separate partition can help prevent unauthorized access to user data and ensure that it does not consume space on the root filesystem.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.3.2 Ensure nodev option set on /home partition
children.Description: The nodev option prevents the creation of device files in the /home directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.3.3 Ensure nosuid option is set on /home partition
children.Description: The nosuid option prevents the execution of setuid and setgid programs in the /home directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.4 Configure /var
children.Description: The /var directory is used for variable data such as logs and spool files. Configuring it as a separate partition can enhance security by isolating variable data from system files and preventing unauthorized access to sensitive data.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.4.1 Ensure separate partition exists for /var
children.Description: Having /var as a separate partition can help prevent unauthorized access to variable data and ensure that it does not consume space on the root filesystem.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.4.2 Ensure nodev option is set on /var partition
children.Description: The nodev option prevents the creation of device files in the /var directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.4.3 Ensure nosuid option is set on /var partition
children.Description: The nosuid option prevents the execution of setuid and setgid programs in the /var directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.5 Configure /var/tmp
children.Description: The /var/tmp directory is used for temporary files that need to persist across reboots. Configuring it as a separate partition can enhance security by isolating temporary files from other filesystems and preventing unauthorized access to sensitive data.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.5.1 Ensure /var/tmp is mounted as a separate partition
children.Description: Having /var/tmp as a separate partition can help prevent unauthorized access to temporary files and ensure that it does not consume space on the root filesystem.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.5.2 Ensure nodev option is set on /var/tmp partition
children.Description: The nodev option prevents the creation of device files in the /var/tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.5.3 Ensure nosuid option is set on /var/tmp partition
children.Description: The nosuid option prevents the execution of setuid and setgid programs in the /var/tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.5.4 Ensure noexec option is set on /var/tmp partition
children.Description: The noexec option prevents the execution of binaries in the /var/tmp directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.6 Configure /var/log
children.Description: The /var/log directory is used for log files. Configuring it as a separate partition can enhance security by isolating log files from other filesystems and preventing unauthorized access to sensitive log data.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.6.1 Ensure separate partition exists for /var/log
children.Description: Having /var/log as a separate partition can help prevent unauthorized access to log files and ensure that it does not consume space on the root filesystem.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.6.2 Ensure nodev option is set on /var/log partition
children.Description: The nodev option prevents the creation of device files in the /var/log directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.6.3 Ensure nosuid option is set on /var/log partition
children.Description: The nosuid option prevents the execution of setuid and setgid programs in the /var/log directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.6.4 Ensure noexec option is set on /var/log partition
children.Description: The noexec option prevents the execution of binaries in the /var/log directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.7 Configure /var/log/audit
children.Description: The auditing daemon, auditd, stores log data in the /var/log/audit directory.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.7.1 Ensure separate partition exists for /var/log/audit
children.Description: The auditing daemon, auditd, stores log data in the /var/log/audit directory.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.7.2 Ensure nodev option is set on /var/log/audit partition
children.Description: The nodev option prevents the creation of device files in the /var/log/audit directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.7.3 Ensure nosuid option is set on /var/log/audit partition
children.Description: The nosuid option prevents the execution of setuid and setgid programs in the /var/log/audit directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.1.2.7.4 Ensure noexec option is set on /var/log/audit partition
children.Description: The noexec option prevents the execution of binaries in the /var/log/audit directory, which can help mitigate security risks.

children.Summary: 1.2 Package Management
children.Description: Package management is a critical aspect of system security, ensuring that the software installed on the system is up-to-date and free from known vulnerabilities. This section provides guidance on how to manage packages effectively, including installing, updating, and removing software packages.

children.Summary: 1.2.1 Configure Package Repositories
children.Description: Configuring package repositories ensures that the system can access trusted sources for software packages, reducing the risk of installing malicious or outdated software.

children.Summary: 1.2.1.1 Ensure GPG keys are configured
children.Description: GPG keys are used to verify the authenticity of packages. Ensuring that GPG keys are configured helps prevent the installation of tampered or malicious packages.

children.Summary: 1.2.1.2 Ensure package manager repositories are configured
children.Description: Configuring package manager repositories ensures that the system can access trusted sources for software packages, reducing the risk of installing malicious or outdated software.

children.Summary: 1.2.2 Configure Packege Updates
children.Description: Configuring package updates ensures that the system is kept up-to-date with the latest security patches and software improvements, reducing the risk of vulnerabilities.

children.Summary: 1.2.2.1 Ensure updates, patches, and additional security software are installed
children.Description: Regularly installing updates, patches, and additional security software helps keep the system secure against known vulnerabilities.

children.Summary: 1.3 Mandatory Access Control
children.Description: Mandatory Access Control (MAC) is a security mechanism that restricts the ability of users and processes to access system resources based on predefined policies. This section provides guidance on how to implement and configure MAC systems to enhance security.

children.Summary: 1.3.1 Configure AppArmor
children.Description: AppArmor is a Linux kernel security module that allows the system administrator to restrict programs' capabilities with per-program profiles. Configuring AppArmor enhances security by limiting the actions that programs can perform.

children.Summary: 1.3.1.1 Ensure AppArmor is installed
children.Description: AppArmor must be installed to provide mandatory access control for applications. It helps in confining programs to a limited set of resources and capabilities.

children.Summary: 1.3.1.2 Ensure AppArmor is enabled in the bootloader configuration
children.Description: Enabling AppArmor in the bootloader configuration ensures that it is activated during system startup, providing mandatory access control from the beginning.

children.Summary: 1.3.1.3 Ensure AppArmor profiles are in enforce mode
children.Description: AppArmor profiles define the access rights for applications. Ensuring that profiles are in enforce mode means that the restrictions defined in the profiles are actively enforced, enhancing security.

children.Summary: 1.3.1.4 Ensure all AppArmor profiles are in enforcing
children.Description: Ensuring that all AppArmor profiles are in enforcing mode means that the restrictions defined in the profiles are actively enforced, enhancing security.

children.Summary: 1.4 Configure Bootloader
children.Description: The bootloader is a critical component of the system that loads the operating system kernel and initializes the system. Configuring the bootloader securely is essential to prevent unauthorized access and ensure the integrity of the system.

children.Summary: 1.4.1 Ensure bootloader password is set
children.Description: Setting a bootloader password prevents unauthorized users from modifying the bootloader configuration or booting into single-user mode, which can bypass security measures.

children.Summary: 1.4.2 Ensure access to bootloader config is configured
children.Description: Configuring access to the bootloader configuration file ensures that only authorized users can modify the bootloader settings, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 1.5 Configure additional Process hardening
children.Description: Process hardening involves applying security measures to processes running on the system to reduce the risk of exploitation. This section provides guidance on how to configure additional process hardening techniques to enhance system security.

children.Summary: 1.5.1 Ensure address space layout randomization is enabled
children.Description: Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) is a security technique that randomizes the memory addresses used by system and application processes, making it more difficult for attackers to predict the location of specific code or data in memory.

children.Summary: 1.5.2 Ensure ptrace_score is restricted
children.Description: Restricting ptrace_score prevents unauthorized processes from tracing or manipulating other processes, which can be used to exploit vulnerabilities or gain unauthorized access to sensitive information.

children.Summary: 1.5.3 Ensure core dumps are restricted
children.Description: Restricting core dumps prevents the creation of core dump files that can contain sensitive information about the system and running processes, which could be exploited by attackers.

children.Summary: 1.5.4 Ensure prelink is not installed
children.Description: Prelinking is a technique that can improve the performance of dynamically linked applications, but it can also introduce security risks by making it easier for attackers to predict the locations of shared libraries in memory. Ensuring that prelink is not installed helps mitigate these risks.

children.Summary: 1.5.5 Ensure Automatic Error Reporting is not enabled
children.Description: Automatic Error Reporting can send sensitive information about the system and running processes to external servers, which could be exploited by attackers. Ensuring that Automatic Error Reporting is not enabled helps protect sensitive information.

children.Summary: 1.6 Configure Command Line Warning Banner
children.Description: A command line warning banner is a message displayed to users when they log in to the system via the command line. Configuring a command line warning banner helps inform users about security policies and legal notices, and can deter unauthorized access.

children.Summary: 1.6.1 Ensure message of the day is configured properly
children.Description: The message of the day (MOTD) is a message displayed to users when they log in to the system. Configuring it properly helps inform users about security policies and legal notices.

children.Summary: 1.6.2 Ensure local login warning banner is configured properly
children.Description: A local login warning banner is displayed to users when they log in to the system via the console. Configuring it properly helps inform users about security policies and legal notices.

children.Summary: 1.6.3 Ensure remote login warning banner is configured properly
children.Description: A remote login warning banner is displayed to users when they log in to the system via SSH or other remote access methods. Configuring it properly helps inform users about security policies and legal notices.

children.Summary: 1.6.4 Ensure access to /etc/motd is configured
children.Description: Configuring access to the /etc/motd file ensures that only authorized users can modify the message of the day, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 1.6.5 Ensure access to /etc/issue is configured
children.Description: Configuring access to the /etc/issue file ensures that only authorized users can modify the login banner, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 1.6.6 Ensure access to /etc/issue.net is configured
children.Description: Configuring access to the /etc/issue.net file ensures that only authorized users can modify the remote login banner, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 1.7 Configure GNOME Display Manager
children.Description: The GNOME Display Manager (GDM) is the default display manager for GNOME desktop environments. Configuring GDM securely is essential to prevent unauthorized access and ensure the integrity of the graphical user interface.

children.Summary: 1.7.1 Ensure GDM is removed
children.Description: Removing GDM can enhance security by reducing the attack surface of the system, especially if a different display manager is preferred or if the system does not require a graphical user interface.

children.Summary: 1.7.2 Ensure GDM login banner is configured
children.Description: Configuring the GDM login banner helps inform users about security policies and legal notices when they log in to the graphical user interface.

children.Summary: 1.7.3 Ensure GDM disable-user-list option is enabled
children.Description: Enabling the disable-user-list option in GDM prevents unauthorized users from viewing the list of available user accounts on the login screen, enhancing security by obscuring user information.

children.Summary: 1.7.4 Ensure GDM screen locks when the user is idle
children.Description: Configuring GDM to lock the screen when the user is idle helps protect the system from unauthorized access when users leave their workstations unattended.

children.Summary: 1.7.5 Ensure GDM screen locks cannot be overridden
children.Description: Configuring GDM to prevent users from overriding the screen lock settings helps ensure that the system remains secure when users leave their workstations unattended.

children.Summary: 1.7.6 Ensure GDM automatic mounting of removable media is disabled
children.Description: Disabling the automatic mounting of removable media in GDM helps prevent unauthorized access to potentially malicious or untrusted media, enhancing system security.

children.Summary: 1.7.7 Ensure GDM disabling automatic mounting of removable media is not overridden
children.Description: Ensuring that the disabling of automatic mounting of removable media cannot be overridden helps maintain the security posture of the system by preventing users from enabling potentially risky behavior.

children.Summary: 1.7.8 Ensure GDM autorun-never is enabled
children.Description: Enabling autorun in GDM allows the system to automatically run specific applications or scripts when a user logs in, which can be useful for security monitoring or compliance purposes.

children.Summary: 1.7.9 Ensure GDM autorun-never cannot be overridden
children.Description: Ensuring that the autorun-never setting cannot be overridden helps maintain the security posture of the system by preventing users from enabling potentially risky behavior.

children.Summary: 1.7.10 Ensure XDCMP is disabled
children.Description: Disabling XDCMP (X Display Manager Control Protocol) prevents remote access to the graphical user interface, enhancing security by reducing the attack surface of the system.

Description: While applying system updates and patches helps correct known vulnerabilities, one of the best ways to protect the system against as yet unreported vulnerabilities is to disable all services that are not required for normal system operation. This prevents the exploitation of vulnerabilities discovered at a later date. If a service is not enabled, it cannot be exploited. The actions in this section of the document provide guidance on some services which can be safely disabled and under which circumstances, greatly reducing the number of possible threats to the resulting system. Additionally, some services which should remain enabled but with secure configuration are covered as well as insecure service clients.

children.Summary: 2.1 Configure Server Services
children.Description: Server services are essential for the operation of the system and should be configured to ensure security and functionality.

children.Summary: 2.1.1 Ensure autofs services are not in use
children.Description: Autofs is a service that automatically mounts filesystems on demand. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.2 Ensure avahi-daemon services are not in use
children.Description: Avahi-daemon is a service that provides mDNS/DNS-SD services. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.3 Ensure dhcp services are not in use
children.Description: DHCP services are used to assign IP addresses dynamically. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.4 Ensure dns services are not in use
children.Description: DNS services are used to resolve domain names to IP addresses. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.5 Ensure dnsmasq services are not in use
children.Description: Dnsmasq is a lightweight DNS forwarder and DHCP server. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.6 Ensure ftp services are not in use
children.Description: FTP services are used for file transfer. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.7 Ensure ldap services are not in use
children.Description: LDAP services are used for directory services. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.8 Ensure message access services are not in use
children.Description: Message access services are used for inter-process communication. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.9 Ensure network file system services are not in use
children.Description: Network file system services are used for sharing files over the network. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.10 Ensure nis services are not in use
children.Description: NIS (Network Information Service) is used for distributing system configuration data. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.11 Ensure print server services are not in use
children.Description: Print server services are used for managing printers over the network. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.12 Ensure rpcbind services are not in use
children.Description: Rpcbind is used to map RPC program numbers to universal addresses. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.13 Ensure rsync services are not in use
children.Description: Rsync is used for synchronizing files and directories between systems. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.14 Ensure samba services are not in use
children.Description: Samba is used for sharing files and printers with Windows systems. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.15 Ensure snmp services are not in use
children.Description: SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) is used for network management. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.16 Ensure tftp services are not in use
children.Description: TFTP (Trivial File Transfer Protocol) is a simple file transfer protocol. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.17 Ensure web proxy services are not in use
children.Description: Web proxy services are used for caching and filtering web traffic. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.18 Ensure web server services are not in use
children.Description: Web server services are used for hosting websites. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.19 Ensure xinetd services are not in use
children.Description: Xinetd is a super-server daemon that manages internet services. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.20 Ensure X windows server services are not in use
children.Description: X Windows server services are used for providing a graphical user interface. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.1.21 Ensure mail transfer agent is configured for local-only mode
children.Description: Configuring the mail transfer agent (MTA) for local-only mode ensures that it only accepts and delivers mail locally, preventing it from being used as an open relay for sending spam or malicious emails.

children.Summary: 2.1.22 Ensure only approved services are listening on a network interface
children.Description: Ensuring that only approved services are listening on a network interface helps reduce the attack surface by preventing unauthorized access to services that are not needed for normal operation.

children.Summary: 2.2 Configure Client Services
children.Description: Client services are used to connect to remote systems and should be configured securely to prevent unauthorized access.

children.Summary: 2.2.1 Ensure NIS client is not installed
children.Description: NIS (Network Information Service) is used for distributing system configuration data. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.2.2 Ensure rsh client is not installed
children.Description: RSH (Remote Shell) is an insecure protocol for remote command execution. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.2.3 Ensure talk client is not installed
children.Description: Talk is a command-line utility for real-time communication between users. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.2.4 Ensure telnet client is not installed
children.Description: Telnet is an insecure protocol for remote command execution. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.2.5 Ensure ldap client is not installed
children.Description: LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) is used for accessing directory services. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.2.6 Ensure ftp client is not installed
children.Description: FTP (File Transfer Protocol) is an insecure protocol for transferring files. If not needed, it should be disabled to reduce the attack surface.

children.Summary: 2.3 Configure Time Synchronization
children.Description: Time synchronization is essential for maintaining accurate timestamps on system logs and ensuring that scheduled tasks run at the correct times. This section provides guidance on how to configure time synchronization services securely.

children.Summary: 2.3.1 Ensure time syncronization is in use
children.Description: Time synchronization ensures that the system clock is accurate, which is crucial for logging events, scheduling tasks, and maintaining security protocols.

children.Summary: 2.3.1.1 Ensure a single time synchronization daemon is in use
children.Description: Using a single time synchronization daemon prevents conflicts and ensures that the system clock is synchronized with a reliable time source.

children.Summary: 2.3.2 Configure systemd-timesyncd
children.Description: systemd-timesyncd is a lightweight time synchronization service that is part of the systemd suite. Configuring it ensures that the system clock is synchronized with network time servers.

children.Summary: 2.3.2.1 Ensure systemd-timesyncd configured with authorized timeserver
children.Description: Configuring systemd-timesyncd with an authorized time server ensures that the system clock is synchronized with a trusted source, enhancing the accuracy and reliability of timekeeping.

children.Summary: 2.3.2.2 Ensure systemd-timesyncd is enabled and running
children.Description: Enabling and running systemd-timesyncd ensures that the time synchronization service is active and continuously synchronizing the system clock with the configured time server.

children.Summary: 2.3.3 Configure chrony
children.Description: Chrony is a versatile time synchronization service that can be used as an alternative to systemd-timesyncd. It is particularly useful for systems that are not always connected to the network.

children.Summary: 2.3.3.1 Ensure chrony is configured with authorized timeserver
children.Description: Configuring chrony with an authorized time server ensures that the system clock is synchronized with a trusted source, enhancing the accuracy and reliability of timekeeping.

children.Summary: 2.3.3.2 Ensure chrony is running as user_chrony
children.Description: Running chrony as a dedicated user (user_chrony) enhances security by isolating the time synchronization service from other system processes, reducing the risk of privilege escalation.

children.Summary: 2.4 Job Schedulers
children.Description: Job schedulers are used to automate the execution of tasks at specified times or intervals. This section provides guidance on how to configure job schedulers securely.

children.Summary: 2.4.1 Configure cron
children.Description: Cron is a time-based job scheduler in Unix-like operating systems. It allows users to schedule jobs (commands or scripts) to run at specific times or intervals.

children.Summary: 2.4.1.1 Ensure cron daemon is enabled and active
children.Description: Enabling and activating the cron daemon ensures that scheduled jobs are executed as intended, maintaining system functionality and automation.

children.Summary: 2.4.1.2 Ensure permissions on /etc/crontab are configured
children.Description: Configuring permissions on /etc/crontab ensures that only authorized users can modify the system-wide cron jobs, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 2.4.1.3 Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.hourly are configured
children.Description: Configuring permissions on /etc/cron.hourly ensures that only authorized users can modify the hourly cron jobs, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 2.4.1.4 Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.daily are configured
children.Description: Configuring permissions on /etc/cron.daily ensures that only authorized users can modify the daily cron jobs, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 2.4.1.5 Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.weekly are configured
children.Description: Configuring permissions on /etc/cron.weekly ensures that only authorized users can modify the weekly cron jobs, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 2.4.1.6 Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.monthly are configured
children.Description: Configuring permissions on /etc/cron.monthly ensures that only authorized users can modify the monthly cron jobs, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 2.4.1.7 Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.d are configured
children.Description: Configuring permissions on /etc/cron.d ensures that only authorized users can modify the cron jobs defined in this directory, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 2.4.1.8 Ensure crontab is restricted to authorized users
children.Description: Restricting crontab access to authorized users ensures that only trusted users can create or modify scheduled jobs, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

children.Summary: 2.4.2 Configure at
children.Description: At is a command-line utility that allows users to schedule one-time tasks to be executed at a specified time in the future.

children.Summary: 2.4.2.1 Ensure at is restricted to authorized users
children.Description: Restricting at access to authorized users ensures that only trusted users can create or modify scheduled one-time tasks, preventing unauthorized changes that could compromise system security.

Description: This section provides guidance on for securing the network configuration of the system.

children.Summary: 3.1 Configure Network Devices
children.Description: To reduce the attack surface of a system unused devices should be disabled.

children.Summary: 3.1.1 Ensure IPv6 status is identified
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Internet Protocol Version 6 (IPv6) is the most recent version of Internet Protocol (IP). It's designed to supply IP addressing and additional security to support the predicted growth of connected devices. IPv6 is based on 128-bit addressing and can support 340 undecillion, which is 340 trillion3 addresses.

children.Summary: 3.1.2 Ensure wireless interfaces are disabled
Label: Level 1 - Server
children.Description: Wireless networking is used when wired networks are unavailable

children.Summary: 3.1.3 Ensure Bluetooth services are not in use
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Bluetooth is a short-range wireless technology standard that is used for exchanging data between devices over short distances. It employs UHF radio waves in the ISM bands, from 2.402 GHz to 2.48 GHz. It is mainly used as an alternative to wire connections.

children.Summary: 3.2 Configure Network Kernel Modules
children.Description: The Linux kernel modules support several network protocols that are not commonly used. If these protocols are not needed, it is recommended that they be disabled in the kernel.

children.Summary: 3.2.1 Ensure dccp kernel module is not available
Label: Level 2 - Server
Level 2 - Workstation
children.Description: The Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) is a transport layer protocol that supports streaming media and telephony. DCCP provides a way to gain access to congestion control, without having to do it at the application layer, but does not provide in-sequence delivery.

children.Summary: 3.2.2 Ensure tipc kernel module is not available
Label: Level 2 - Server
Level 2 - Workstation
children.Description: The Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC) protocol is designed to provide communication between cluster nodes.

children.Summary: 3.2.3 Ensure rds kernel module is not available
Label: Level 2 - Server
Level 2 - Workstation
children.Description: The Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol is a transport layer protocol that is used to provide reliable, in-order delivery of datagrams. It is designed for high-performance computing applications.

children.Summary: 3.2.4 Ensure sctp kernel module is not available
Label: Level 2 - Server
Level 2 - Workstation
children.Description: The Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) is a transport layer protocol that is used to provide reliable, in-order delivery of messages. It is designed for high-performance computing applications.

children.Summary: 3.3 Configure Network Kernel Parameters
children.Description: The Linux kernel provides several parameters that can be used to configure the network stack. These parameters can be used to improve the performance and security of the network stack.

children.Summary: 3.3.1 Ensure ip forwarding is disabled
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: The net.ipv4.ip_forward and net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding flags are used to tell the system whether it can forward packets or not.

children.Summary: 3.3.2 Ensure packet redirect sending is disabled
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: ICMP Redirects are used to send routing information to other hosts. As a host itself does not act as a router (in a host only configuration), there is no need to send redirects.

children.Summary: 3.3.3 Ensure bogus icmp responses are ignored
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Setting net.ipv4.icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses to 1 prevents the kernel from logging bogus responses (RFC-1122 non-compliant) from broadcast reframes, keeping file systems from filling up with useless log messages.

children.Summary: 3.3.4 Ensure broadcast icmp requests are ignored
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Setting net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts to 1 prevents the kernel from responding to ICMP echo requests sent to broadcast addresses.

children.Summary: 3.3.5 Ensure icmp redirects are not accepted
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects to 0 prevents the kernel from accepting ICMP redirects. This is important because ICMP redirects can be used to redirect traffic to a malicious host.

children.Summary: 3.3.6 Ensure secure icmp redirects are not accepted
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.secure_redirects to 0 prevents the kernel from accepting secure ICMP redirects. This is important because secure ICMP redirects can be used to redirect traffic to a malicious host.

children.Summary: 3.3.7 Ensure reverse path filtering is enabled
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Reverse Path Filtering (RPF) is a security feature that is used to prevent IP spoofing. It works by checking the source address of incoming packets against the routing table to ensure that the packet is coming from a valid source.

children.Summary: 3.3.8 Ensure source routed packets are not accepted
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Source routing is a feature that allows the sender of a packet to specify the route that the packet should take through the network. This can be used to bypass security controls and is therefore not recommended.

children.Summary: 3.3.9 Ensure suspicious packets are logged
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians to 1 enables logging of suspicious packets, which can help identify potential attacks.

children.Summary: 3.3.10 Ensure tcp syn cookies are enabled
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: TCP SYN cookies are a security feature that is used to prevent SYN flood attacks. They work by encoding the TCP sequence number in the SYN-ACK packet, which allows the server to verify that the client is legitimate.

children.Summary: 3.3.11 Ensure ipv6 router advertisements are not accepted
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: IPv6 Router Advertisements (RAs) are used to discover the presence of routers on the network. However, they can also be used to redirect traffic to a malicious host. Therefore, it is recommended to disable them.

Description: Host-based firewalls are software applications that monitor and control incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules. They are installed on individual hosts or devices, providing a layer of security that is specific to that host.

children.Summary: 4.1 Configure Uncomplicated Firewall (UFW)
children.Description: Uncomplicated Firewall (UFW) is a user-friendly interface for managing iptables firewall rules. It is designed to make managing a netfilter firewall easier, and is particularly well-suited for host-based firewalls.

children.Summary: 4.1.1 Ensure ufw is installed
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Uncomplicated Firewall (UFW) is a user-friendly interface for managing iptables firewall rules. It is designed to make managing a netfilter firewall easier, and is particularly well-suited for host-based firewalls.

children.Summary: 4.1.2 Ensure iptables-persistent is not installed with ufw
Label: Level 1 - Server, Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: The iptables-persistent package is used to save and restore iptables rules. However, it is not compatible with UFW, which manages its own rules. Therefore, it is recommended to ensure that iptables-persistent is not installed when using UFW.

children.Summary: 4.1.3 Ensure ufw service is enabled
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: The UFW service must be enabled to ensure that the firewall rules are applied at system startup. This is important for maintaining the security posture of the host.

children.Summary: 4.1.4 Ensure ufw loopback traffic is configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: The loopback interface is used for internal communication within the host. It is important to ensure that traffic on the loopback interface is allowed, as it is used by many applications for inter-process communication.

children.Summary: 4.1.5 Ensure ufw outbound connections are configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Outbound connections are those initiated from the host to external networks. It is important to configure outbound connections to allow necessary traffic while blocking unwanted connections.

children.Summary: 4.1.6 Ensure ufw firewall rules exist for all open ports
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: All open ports on the host should have corresponding UFW firewall rules to ensure that only authorized traffic is allowed. This helps to prevent unauthorized access and potential attacks.

children.Summary: 4.1.7 Ensure ufw default deny firewall policy is configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: The default deny policy for UFW ensures that all incoming traffic is blocked unless explicitly allowed by a rule. This is a fundamental security measure to prevent unauthorized access to the host.

children.Summary: 4.2 Configure nftables
children.Description: nftables is a framework provided by the Linux kernel for packet filtering, network address translation (NAT), and other packet mangling. It replaces the older iptables framework and provides a more efficient and flexible way to manage firewall rules.

children.Summary: 4.2.1 Ensure nftables is installed
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: nftables is a framework provided by the Linux kernel for packet filtering, network address translation (NAT), and other packet mangling. It replaces the older iptables framework and provides a more efficient and flexible way to manage firewall rules.

children.Summary: 4.2.2 Ensure ufw is uninstalled or disabled with nftables
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: If nftables is being used, it is recommended to uninstall or disable UFW, as they can conflict with each other. This ensures that nftables can manage all firewall rules without interference.

children.Summary: 4.2.3 Ensure iptables are flushed with nftables
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: When switching to nftables, it is important to flush existing iptables rules to avoid conflicts. This ensures that nftables can start with a clean slate and manage all firewall rules effectively.

children.Summary: 4.2.4 Ensure a nftables table exists
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: A nftables table is a collection of chains and rules. It is important to ensure that at least one table exists to manage firewall rules effectively.

children.Summary: 4.2.5 Ensure a nftables base chain exists
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: A base chain is a default chain that is used to manage incoming and outgoing traffic. It is important to ensure that a base chain exists to provide a foundation for managing firewall rules.

children.Summary: 4.2.6 Ensure nftables loopback traffic is configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: The loopback interface is used for internal communication within the host. It is important to ensure that traffic on the loopback interface is allowed, as it is used by many applications for inter-process communication.

children.Summary: 4.2.7 Ensure nftables outbound and stablished connections are configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Outbound connections are those initiated from the host to external networks. It is important to configure outbound connections to allow necessary traffic while blocking unwanted connections. Established connections should also be allowed to ensure that ongoing communications are not disrupted.

children.Summary: 4.2.8 Ensure nftables default deny firewall policy is configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: The default deny policy for nftables ensures that all incoming traffic is blocked unless explicitly allowed by a rule. This is a fundamental security measure to prevent unauthorized access to the host.

children.Summary: 4.2.9 Ensure nftables service is enabled
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: The nftables service must be enabled to ensure that the firewall rules are applied at system startup. This is important for maintaining the security posture of the host.

children.Summary: 4.2.10 Ensure nftables rules are permanent
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: It is important to ensure that nftables rules are permanent, meaning they persist across reboots. This ensures that the firewall rules remain in effect even after the host is restarted.

children.Summary: 4.3 Configure iptables
children.Description: Iptables is a user-space utility program that allows a system administrator to configure the IP packet filter rules of the Linux kernel firewall, implemented as different Netfilter modules. It is used to set up, maintain, and inspect the tables of IP packet filter rules in the Linux kernel.

children.Summary: 4.3.1 Configure iptables software
children.Description: Iptables is a user-space utility program that allows a system administrator to configure the IP packet filter rules of the Linux kernel firewall, implemented as different Netfilter modules. It is used to set up, maintain, and inspect the tables of IP packet filter rules in the Linux kernel.

children.Summary: 4.3.1.1 Ensure iptables packages are installed
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Iptables is a user-space utility program that allows a system administrator to configure the IP packet filter rules of the Linux kernel firewall, implemented as different Netfilter modules. It is used to set up, maintain, and inspect the tables of IP packet filter rules in the Linux kernel.

children.Summary: 4.3.1.2 Ensure nftables is not installed with iptables
Label: Level 1 - Server, Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: If nftables is being used, it is recommended to uninstall or disable iptables, as they can conflict with each other. This ensures that nftables can manage all firewall rules without interference.

children.Summary: 4.3.1.3 Ensure ufw is uninstalled or disabled with iptables
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: If iptables is being used, it is recommended to uninstall or disable UFW, as they can conflict with each other. This ensures that iptables can manage all firewall rules without interference.

children.Summary: 4.3.2 Configure IPv4 iptables
children.Description: Iptables is a user-space utility program that allows a system administrator to configure the IP packet filter rules of the Linux kernel firewall, implemented as different Netfilter modules. It is used to set up, maintain, and inspect the tables of IP packet filter rules in the Linux kernel. This section focuses on configuring IPv4 iptables specifically.

children.Summary: 4.3.2.1 Ensure iptables default deny firewall policy is configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Setting a default deny policy for iptables ensures that all incoming and outgoing traffic is blocked unless explicitly allowed by a rule. This is a fundamental security measure to protect the system from unauthorized access.

children.Summary: 4.3.2.2 Ensure iptables loopback traffic is configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Configuring loopback traffic in iptables allows the system to communicate with itself. This is essential for many applications and services that rely on local communication, such as web servers and databases.

children.Summary: 4.3.2.3 Ensure iptables outbound and established connections are configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Configuring outbound and established connections in iptables allows the system to maintain active connections and initiate new ones. This is crucial for the functionality of many applications that require network access, such as web browsers and email clients.

children.Summary: 4.3.2.4 Ensure iptables firewall rules exist for all open ports
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Ensuring that iptables firewall rules exist for all open ports is essential for maintaining security. This prevents unauthorized access to services running on those ports and helps to mitigate potential vulnerabilities.

children.Summary: 4.3.3 Configure IPv6 iptables
children.Description: Iptables is a user-space utility program that allows a system administrator to configure the IP packet filter rules of the Linux kernel firewall, implemented as different Netfilter modules. It is used to set up, maintain, and inspect the tables of IP packet filter rules in the Linux kernel. This section focuses on configuring IPv6 iptables specifically.

children.Summary: 4.3.3.1 Ensure ip6tables default deny firewall policy is configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Setting a default deny policy for ip6tables ensures that all incoming and outgoing IPv6 traffic is blocked unless explicitly allowed by a rule. This is a fundamental security measure to protect the system from unauthorized access.

children.Summary: 4.3.3.2 Ensure ip6tables loopback traffic is configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Configuring loopback traffic in ip6tables allows the system to communicate with itself over IPv6. This is essential for many applications and services that rely on local communication, such as web servers and databases.

children.Summary: 4.3.3.3 Ensure ip6tables outbound and established connections are configured
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Configuring outbound and established connections in ip6tables allows the system to maintain active connections and initiate new ones over IPv6. This is crucial for the functionality of many applications that require network access, such as web browsers and email clients.

children.Summary: 4.3.3.4 Ensure ip6tables firewall rules exist for all open ports
Label: Level 1 - Server
Level 1 - Workstation
children.Description: Ensuring that ip6tables firewall rules exist for all open ports is essential for maintaining security. This prevents unauthorized access to services running on those ports and helps to mitigate potential vulnerabilities.

children.Summary: 5.1 Configure SSH Server
children.Description: Secure Shell (SSH) is a secure, encrypted replacement for common login services such as telnet, ftp, rlogin, rsh, and rcp. It is strongly recommended that sites abandon older clear-text login protocols and use SSH to prevent session hijacking and sniffing of sensitive data off the network.

children.Summary: 5.1.1 Ensure Permissions on /etc/ssh/sshd_config are configured
children.Description: The file /etc/ssh/sshd_config, and files ending in .conf in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config.d directory, contain configuration specifications for sshd.

children.Summary: 5.1.2 Ensure permissions on SSH private host key files are configured
children.Description: An SSH private key is one of two files used in SSH public key authentication. In this authentication method, the possession of the private key is proof of identity. Only a private key that corresponds to a public key will be able to authenticate successfully. The private keys need to be stored and handled carefully, and no copies of the private key should be distributed.

children.Summary: 5.1.3 Ensure permissions on SSH public host key files are configured
children.Description: An SSH public key is one of two files used in SSH public key authentication. In this authentication method, a public key is a key that can be used for verifying digital signatures generated using a corresponding private key. Only a public key that corresponds to a private key will be able to authenticate successfully.

children.Summary: 5.1.4 Ensure sshd access is configured
children.Description: To control SSH access, system administrators can use `AllowUsers` or `AllowGroups` to explicitly permit specific users or groups, or `DenyUsers` or `DenyGroups` to block certain users or groups from logging in, with support for restricting by host using the `user@host` format.

children.Summary: 5.1.5 Ensure sshd Banner is configured
children.Description: The Banner parameter specifies a file whose contents must be sent to the remote user before authentication is permitted. By default, no banner is displayed.

children.Summary: 5.1.6 Ensure sshd Ciphers are configured
children.Description: This variable limits the ciphers that SSH can use during communication.

children.Summary: 5.1.7 Ensure sshd ClientAliveInterval and ClientAliveCountMax are configured
children.Description: To clarify, the two settings described below are only meant for idle connections from a protocol perspective and are not meant to check if the user is active or not. An idle user does not mean an idle connection. SSH does not and never had, intentionally, the capability to drop idle users. In SSH versions before 8.2p1 there was a bug that caused these values to behave in such a manner that they were abused to disconnect idle users. This bug has been resolved in 8.2p1 and thus it can no longer be abused disconnect idle users.

children.Summary: 5.1.8 Ensure sshd DisableForwarding is enabled
children.Description: The DisableForwarding parameter disables all forwarding features, including X11, ssh-agent(1), TCP and StreamLocal. This option overrides all other forwarding-related options and may simplify restricted configurations.

children.Summary: 5.1.9 Ensure sshd GSSAPIAuthentication is disabled
children.Description: The GSSAPIAuthentication parameter specifies whether user authentication based on GSSAPI is allowed

children.Summary: 5.1.10 Ensure sshd HostbasedAuthentication is disabled
children.Description: The HostbasedAuthentication parameter specifies if authentication is allowed through trusted hosts via the user of .rhosts, or /etc/hosts.equiv, along with successful public key client host authentication.

children.Summary: 5.1.11 Ensure sshd IgnoreRhosts is enabled
children.Description: The IgnoreRhosts parameter specifies that .rhosts and .shosts files will not be used in RhostsRSAAuthentication or HostbasedAuthentication.

children.Summary: 5.1.12 Ensure sshd KexAlgorithms is configured
children.Description: Key exchange is any method in cryptography by which cryptographic keys are exchanged between two parties, allowing use of a cryptographic algorithm. If the sender and receiver wish to exchange encrypted messages, each must be equipped to encrypt messages to be sent and decrypt messages received

children.Summary: 5.1.13 Ensure sshd LoginGraceTime is configured
children.Description: The LoginGraceTime parameter specifies the time allowed for successful authentication to the SSH server. The longer the Grace period is the more open unauthenticated connections can exist. Like other session controls in this session the Grace Period should be limited to appropriate organizational limits to ensure the service is available for needed access.

children.Summary: 5.1.14 Ensure sshd LogLevel is configured
children.Description: SSH provides several logging levels with varying amounts of verbosity. The DEBUG options are specifically not recommended other than strictly for debugging SSH communications. These levels provide so much data that it is difficult to identify important security information, and may violate the privacy of users.

children.Summary: 5.1.15 Ensure sshd MACs are configured
children.Description: This variable limits the types of MAC algorithms that SSH can use during communication.

children.Summary: 5.1.16 Ensure sshd MaxAuthTries is configured
children.Description: The MaxAuthTries parameter specifies the maximum number of authentication attempts permitted per connection. When the login failure count reaches half the number, error messages will be written to the syslog file detailing the login failure.

children.Summary: 5.1.17 Ensure sshd MaxSessions is configured
children.Description: The MaxSessions parameter specifies the maximum number of open sessions permitted from a given connection.

children.Summary: 5.1.18 Ensure sshd MaxStartups is configured
children.Description: The MaxStartups parameter specifies the maximum number of concurrent unauthenticated connections to the SSH daemon.

children.Summary: 5.1.19 Ensure sshd PermitEmptyPasswords is disabled
children.Description: The PermitEmptyPasswords parameter specifies if the SSH server allows login to accounts with empty password strings.

children.Summary: 5.1.20 Ensure sshd PermitRootLogin is disabled
children.Description: The PermitRootLogin parameter specifies if the root user can log in using SSH. The default is prohibit-password.

children.Summary: 5.1.21 Ensure sshd PermitUserEnvironment is disabled
children.Description: The PermitUserEnvironment option allows users to present environment options to the SSH daemon.

children.Summary: 5.1.22 Ensure sshd UsePAM is enabled
children.Description: The UsePAM directive enables the Pluggable Authentication Module (PAM) interface. If set to yes this will enable PAM authentication using ChallengeResponseAuthentication and PasswordAuthentication directives in addition to PAM account and session module processing for all authentication types.

children.Summary: 5.2 Configure privilege escalation
children.Description: There are various tools which allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user, as specified by the security policy.

children.Summary: 5.2.1 Ensure sudo is installed
children.Description: sudo allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user, as specified by the security policy. The invoking user's real (not effective) user ID is used to determine the user name with which to query the security policy.

children.Summary: 5.2.2 Ensure sudo commands use pty
children.Description: sudo can be configured to run only from a pseudo terminal (pseudo-pty).

children.Summary: 5.2.3 Ensure sudo log file exists
children.Description: sudo can use a custom log file

children.Summary: 5.2.4 Ensure users must provide password for privilege escalation
children.Description: The operating system must be configured so that users must provide a password for privilege escalation.

children.Summary: 5.2.5 Ensure re-authentication for privilege escalation is not disabled globally
children.Description: The operating system must be configured so that users must re-authenticate for privilege escalation.

children.Summary: 5.2.6 Ensure sudo authentication timeout is configured correctly
children.Description: sudo caches used credentials for a default of 15 minutes. This is for ease of use when there are multiple administrative tasks to perform. The timeout can be modified to suit local security policies. This default is distribution specific. See audit section for further information.

children.Summary: 5.2.7 Ensure access to the su command is restricted
children.Description: The su command allows a user to run a command or shell as another user. The program has been superseded by sudo, which allows for more granular control over privileged access. Normally, the su command can be executed by any user. By uncommenting the pam_wheel.so statement in /etc/pam.d/su, the su command will only allow users in a specific groups to execute su. This group should be empty to reinforce the use of sudo for privileged access.

children.Summary: 5.3 Pluggable Authentication Modules
5.3.1 Configure PAM software packages
children.Description: Updated versions of PAM includes additional functionality

children.Summary: 5.3.1.1 Ensure latest version of pam is installed
children.Description: Updated versions of PAM include additional functionality

children.Summary: 5.3.1.2 Ensure libpam-modules is installed
children.Description: Pluggable Authentication Modules for PAM

children.Summary: 5.3.1.3 Ensure libpam-pwquality is installed
children.Description: libpwquality provides common functions for password quality checking and scoring them based on their apparent randomness. The library also provides a function for generating random passwords with good pronounceability

children.Summary: 5.3.2 Configure pam-auth-update profiles
children.Description: pam-auth-update is a utility that permits configuring the central authentication policy for the system using pre-defined profiles as supplied by PAM module packages. Profiles - Shipped in the /usr/share/pam-configs/ directory specify the modules, with options, to enable; the preferred ordering with respect to other profiles; and whether a profile should be enabled by default. Packages providing PAM modules register their profiles at install time by calling pam-auth-update --package. Selection of profiles is done using the standard debconf interface. The profile selection question will be asked at medium priority when packages are added or removed, so no user interaction is required by default. Users may invoke pam-auth-update directly to change their authentication configuration. The pam-auth-update script makes every effort to respect local changes to /etc/pam.d/common-*. Local modifications to the list of module options will be preserved, and additions of modules within the managed portion of the stack will cause pam-auth-update to treat the config files as locally modified and not make further changes to the config files unless given the --force option. If the user specifies that pam-auth-update should override local configuration changes, the locally-modified files will be saved in /etc/pam.d/ with a suffix of .pam-old.

children.Summary: 5.3.2.1 Ensure pam_unix module is enabled
children.Description: pam_unix is the standard Unix authentication module. It uses standard calls from the system's libraries to retrieve and set account information as well as authentication. Usually this is obtained from the /etc/passwd and if shadow is enabled, the /etc/shadow file as well. The account component performs the task of establishing the status of the user's account and password based on the following shadow elements: expire, last_change, max_change, min_change, warn_change. In the case of the latter, it may offer advice to the user on changing their password or, through the PAM_AUTHTOKEN_REQD return, delay giving service to the user until they have established a new password. The entries listed above are documented in the shadow(5) manual page. Should the user's record not contain one or more of these entries, the corresponding shadow check is not performed. The authentication component performs the task of checking the users credentials (password). The default action of this module is to not permit the user access to a service if their official password is blank

children.Summary: 5.3.2.2 Ensure pam_faillock module is enabled
children.Description: The pam_faillock.so module maintains a list of failed authentication attempts per user during a specified interval and locks the account in case there were more than the configured number of consecutive failed authentications (this is defined by the deny parameter in the faillock configuration). It stores the failure records into per-user files in the tally directory.

children.Summary: 5.3.2.3 Ensure pam_pwquality module is enabled
children.Description: The pam_pwquality.so module performs password quality checking. This module can be plugged into the password stack of a given service to provide strength-checking for passwords. The code was originally based on pam_cracklib module and the module is backwards compatible with its options. The action of this module is to prompt the user for a password and check its strength against a system dictionary and a set of rules for identifying poor choices. The first action is to prompt for a single password, check its strength and then, if it is considered strong, prompt for the password a second time (to verify that it was typed correctly on the first occasion). All being well, the password is passed on to subsequent modules to be installed as the new authentication token.

children.Summary: 5.3.2.4 Ensure pam_pwhistory module is enabled
children.Description: The pam_pwhistory.so module saves the last passwords for each user in order to force password change history and keep the user from alternating between the same password too frequently. This module does not work together with kerberos. In general, it does not make much sense to use this module in conjunction with NIS or LDAP, since the old passwords are stored on the local machine and are not available on another machine for password history checking.

children.Summary: 5.3.3 Configure PAM Arguments
children.Description: Pluggable Authentication Modules (PAM) uses arguments to pass information to a pluggable module during authentication for a particular module type. These arguments allow the PAM configuration files for particular programs to use a common PAM module but in different ways. Invalid arguments are ignored and do not otherwise affect the success or failure of the PAM module. When an invalid argument is passed, an error is usually written to /var/log/messages file. However, since the reporting method is controlled by the PAM module, the module must be written correctly to log the error to this file. Note: If custom PAM files are being used, for this section's remediation, the corresponding files in /etc/pam.d/ would need to be edited directly, and the pam-auth- update --enable <EDITED_PROFILE_NAME> command skipped

children.Summary: 5.3.3.1 Configure pam_faillock module
children.Description: `pam_faillock.so` is a PAM module used to manage account lockouts after multiple failed authentication attempts. It helps protect against brute-force attacks by tracking failed logins and locking user accounts when thresholds are exceeded. By default, it stores failure records in `/var/run/faillock`, though this directory is usually cleared on reboot. To retain failure records across reboots, a different directory should be specified using the `dir=` option. The `audit` option logs failed attempts when the user isn't found, while `silent` suppresses user-facing messages. If `no_log_info` is set, the system wont log informational messages via syslog. The `local_users_only` option ensures only users listed in `/etc/passwd` are tracked, ignoring centralized accounts (like LDAP or AD), and avoids double-lockouts. With `nodelay`, the system wont impose a delay after failed logins. The `deny=n` option sets how many consecutive failures are allowed before locking the account, with the default being 3. The `fail_interval=n` specifies how many seconds those failures must occur within (default: 900 seconds or 15 minutes). The `unlock_time=n` option determines how long the account remains locked (default: 600 seconds or 10 minutes), with `0` meaning it stays locked until manually reset with the `faillock` command. If `even_deny_root` is set, the root account can also be locked, and `root_unlock_time=n` controls how long root stays locked. If not specified, it defaults to the `unlock_time`. The `admin_group=name` option applies root-like lockout behavior to members of the specified group.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.1.1 Ensure password failed attempts lockout is configured
children.Description: The deny=<n> option will deny access if the number of consecutive authentication failures for this user during the recent interval exceeds .

children.Summary: 5.3.3.1.2 Ensure password unlock time is configured
children.Description: unlock_time=<n> - The access will be re-enabled after seconds after the lock out. The value 0 has the same meaning as value never - the access will not be re-enabled without resetting the faillock entries by the faillock(8) command.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.1.3 Ensure password failed attempts lockout includes root account
children.Description: even_deny_root - Root account can become locked as well as regular accounts root_unlock_time=n - This option implies even_deny_root option. Allow access after n seconds to root account after the account is locked. In case the option is not specified the value is the same as of the unlock_time option.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2 Configure pam_pwquality module
children.Description: The pam_pwquality.so module checks the strength of passwords. It performs checks such as making sure a password is not a dictionary word, it is a certain length, contains a mix of characters (e.g. alphabet, numeric, other) and more.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2.1 Ensure password number of changed characters is configured
children.Description: The pwquality difok option sets the number of characters in a password that must not be present in the old password.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2.2 Ensure minimum password length is configured
children.Description: The minimum password length setting determines the lowers number of characters that make up a password for a user account. There are many different theories about how to determine the best password length for an organization, but perhaps 'passphrase' is a better term than 'password'. The minlen option sets the minimum acceptable size for the new password (plus one if credits are not disabled which is the default). Cannot be set to lower value than 6.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2.3 Ensure password complexity is configured
children.Description: The password complexity can be controlled using five parameters: `minclass` sets the minimum number of character types (digit, uppercase, lowercase, special) required in a password. `dcredit` defines the requirement for digits, with a negative value (e.g., -1) meaning at least one digit is required. `ucredit` works similarly for uppercase letters, `lcredit` for lowercase letters, and `ocredit` for special characters. Negative values in these credit options enforce the presence of that character type in the password.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2.4 Ensure password same consecutive characters is configured
children.Description: The pwquality maxrepeat option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in a new password.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2.5 Ensure password maximum sequential characters is configured
children.Description: The pwquality maxsequence option sets the maximum length of monotonic character sequences in the new password. Examples of such sequence are 12345 or fedcb. The check is disabled if the value is 0. Note: Most such passwords will not pass the simplicity check unless the sequence is only a minor part of the password.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2.6 Ensure password dictionary check is enabled
children.Description: The pwquality dictcheck option sets whether to check for the words from the cracklib dictionary.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2.7 Ensure password quality checking is enforced
children.Description: The pam_pwquality module can be configured to either reject a password if it fails the checks, or only print a warning. This is configured by setting the enforcing=<N> argument. If nonzero, a password will be rejected if it fails the checks, otherwise only a warning message will be provided. This setting applies only to the pam_pwquality module and possibly other applications that explicitly change their behavior based on it. It does not affect pwmake(1) and pwscore(1).

children.Summary: 5.3.3.2.8 Ensure password quality is enforced for the root user
children.Description: If the pwquality enforce_for_root option is enabled, the module will return error on failed check even if the user changing the password is root. This option is off by default which means that just the message about the failed check is printed but root can change the password anyway. Note: The root is not asked for an old password so the checks that compare the old and new password are not performed.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.3 Configure pam_pwhistory module
children.Description: pam_pwhistory - PAM module to remember last passwords pam_history.so module - This module saves the last passwords for each user in order to force password change history and keep the user from alternating between the same password too frequently. This module does not work together with kerberos. In general, it does not make much sense to use this module in conjunction with NIS or LDAP, since the old passwords are stored on the local machine and are not available on another machine for password history checking.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.3.1 Ensure password history remember is configured
children.Description: The /etc/security/opasswd file stores the users' old passwords and can be checked to ensure that users are not recycling recent passwords. The number of passwords remembered is set via the remember argument value in set for the pam_pwhistory module.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.3.2 Ensure password history is enforced for the root user
children.Description: If the pwhistory enforce_for_root option is enabled, the module will enforce password history for the root user as well

children.Summary: 5.3.3.3.3 Ensure pam_pwhistory includes use_authtok
children.Description: use_authtok - When password changing enforce the module to set the new password to the one provided by a previously stacked password module

children.Summary: 5.3.3.4 Configure pam_unix module
children.Description: The pam_unix.so module is the standard Unix authentication module. It uses standard calls from the system's libraries to retrieve and set account information as well as authentication. Usually this is obtained from the /etc/passwd and the /etc/shadow file as well if shadow is enabled.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.4.1 Ensure pam_unix does not include nullok
children.Description: The nullok argument overrides the default action of pam_unix.so to not permit the user access to a service if their official password is blank.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.4.2 Ensure pam_unix does not include remember
children.Description: The remember=n argument saves the last n passwords for each user in /etc/security/opasswd in order to force password change history and keep the user from alternating between the same password too frequently. The MD5 password hash algorithm is used for storing the old passwords. Instead of this option the pam_pwhistory module should be used. The pam_pwhistory module saves the last n passwords for each user in /etc/security/opasswd using the password hash algorithm set on the pam_unix module. This allows for the yescrypt or sha512 hash algorithm to be used.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.4.3 Ensure pam_unix includes a strong password hashing algorithm
children.Description: A cryptographic hash function converts an arbitrary-length input into a fixed length output. Password hashing performs a one-way transformation of a password, turning the password into another string, called the hashed password.

children.Summary: 5.3.3.4.4 Ensure pam_unix includes use_authtok
children.Description: use_authtok - When password changing enforce the module to set the new password to the one provided by a previously stacked password module

children.Summary: 5.4 User Accounts and Environment
children.Description: This section provides guidance on setting up secure defaults for system and user accounts and their environment.

children.Summary: 5.4.1 Configure shadow password suite parameters
children.Description: While a majority of the password control parameters have been moved to PAM, some parameters are still available through the shadow password suite. Any changes made to /etc/login.defs will only be applied if the usermod command is used. If user IDs are added a different way, use the chage command to effect changes to individual user IDs.

children.Summary: 5.4.1.1 Ensure password expiration is configured
